Line 268: Line 268:
The ''[[Unix-like]]'' family is a diverse group of operating systems, with several major sub-categories including [[System V]], [[BSD (operating system)|BSD]], and [[Linux kernel|Linux]]. The name "[[UNIX]]" is a trademark of [[The Open Group]] which licenses it for use with any operating system that has been shown to conform to their definitions. "Unix-like" is commonly used to refer to the large set of operating systems which resemble the original Unix.
The ''[[Unix-like]]'' family is a diverse group of operating systems, with several major sub-categories including [[System V]], [[BSD (operating system)|BSD]], and [[Linux kernel|Linux]]. The name "[[UNIX]]" is a trademark of [[The Open Group]] which licenses it for use with any operating system that has been shown to conform to their definitions. "Unix-like" is commonly used to refer to the large set of operating systems which resemble the original Unix.
â
Unix-like systems run on a wide variety of machine architectures. They are used heavily for [[Server (computing)|servers]] in business, as well as [[workstation]]s in academic and engineering environments. [[Free software]] Unix variants, such as [[GNU]], [[Linux kernel|Linux]] and [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]], are popular in these areas.
+
Unix-like systems run on a wide variety of machine architectures. They are used heavily for [[Server (computing)|servers]] in business, as well as [[workstation]]s in academic and engineering environments. [[Free software]] Unix variants, such as [[GNU]], [[Linux]] and [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]], are popular in these areas.
Some Unix variants like HP's [[HP-UX]] and IBM's [[AIX operating system|AIX]] are designed to run only on that vendor's hardware. Others, such as [[Solaris Operating System|Solaris]], can run on multiple types of hardware, including [[x86]] servers and PCs. Apple's [[Mac OS X]], a [[hybrid kernel]]-based BSD variant derived from [[NeXTSTEP]], [[Mach (kernel)|Mach]], and [[FreeBSD]], has replaced Apple's earlier (non-Unix) Mac OS.
Some Unix variants like HP's [[HP-UX]] and IBM's [[AIX operating system|AIX]] are designed to run only on that vendor's hardware. Others, such as [[Solaris Operating System|Solaris]], can run on multiple types of hardware, including [[x86]] servers and PCs. Apple's [[Mac OS X]], a [[hybrid kernel]]-based BSD variant derived from [[NeXTSTEP]], [[Mach (kernel)|Mach]], and [[FreeBSD]], has replaced Apple's earlier (non-Unix) Mac OS.
